comment.author: 25027041@N00
comment._content: This picture is looking west on Broome (from near Crosby toward Broadway), not looking down Broadway. maps.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&geocode=&q=cro...

comment.author: 8256808@N02
comment._content: From left to right, the main buildings visible are: 435 Broome Street (William A. Potter, 1873) Mechanics & Traders National Bank Building a.k.a. 437-441 Broome Street/486 Broadway (Lamb & Rich, 1882-1883) 443-449 Broome Street a.k.a. 487 Broadway/60 Mercer Street (John T. Williams, 1895-1896): Former New York headquarters for Banco Di Sicilia. E.V. Haughwout Building a.k.a. 488-492 Broadway/440 Broome Street (John P. Gaynor/Daniel D. Badger, 1856-1857): One of the most famous cast-iron buildings in the world. Former location of E.V. Haughwout & Co., a dry-goods company that supplied china to the Pierce and Lincoln presidencies, and the world's first passenger elevator. 438 Broome Street (E. Kilpatrick, 1885) (Primary Source: NYC Landmarks Preservation Commission, SoHo--Cast Iron Historic District Designation Report)
